breakdown.projects: 25% each for Student Presentation Assignment, Simulation Lab 1, Simulation Lab 2, Literature Review Paper

grading.policies: Assignments will receive a 10% penalty within the first week that they are submitted late, which will increase by 10% for each week thereafter.

policies.attendance: Student participation in our weekly synchronous Zoom lectures is highly encouraged.
policies.late_work: Assignments will receive a 10% penalty within the first week that they are submitted late, which will increase by 10% for each week thereafter.
policies.academic_integrity: All Stevens graduate students promise to be fully truthful and avoid dishonesty, fraud, misrepresentation, and deceit of any type in relation to their academic work.
policies.accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology is dedicated to providing appropriate accommodations to students with documented disabilities.

additional_info.technology_requirements: Basic computer and web-browsing skills, Live web conferencing using Zoom, Composing a slide presentation and written report using Microsoft PowerPoint and Word, using MATLAB for programming.
additional_info.support_resources: For more information about course access or support, contact the Technology Resource and Assistance Center (TRAC) by calling 201-216-5500.

_metadata.course_description: Mobile robot geometry, kinematics, and dynamics. Control and estimation for autonomous vehicles. Motion planning, including discrete and continuous methods, and sampling-based planning. Simultaneous localization and mapping, including active SLAM and autonomous exploration with occupancy grids. Markov decision processes and partially observable Markov decision processes with application to mobile robots; planning under uncertainty. Introduction to supervised learning and reinforcement learning, including deep learning. Applications of machine learning to autonomous navigation.
learning_outcomes: Apply the techniques of control system design and state estimation design to mobile robotic systems
Model the disturbances that contribute uncertainty to mobile robotic systems
Use computer simulation as a tool for predicting the performance of a mobile robot and parameterizing a suitable navigation solution
Analyze the robotics research literature to understand contemporary issues of your interest in mobile robot navigation
Evaluate modeling assumptions and algorithms to solve localization, mapping, and planning problems
